Issues.Title: Add an InputScopeNameValue for IP-address input
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/blob/master/Documentation/issue-guide.md -->

Currently there are no predefined InputScopeNameValue that applies to IP-addresses. The numeric ones does not show up the punctuation character for Swedish virtual keyboards (where comma is displayed instead). A virtual keyboard layout with numeric keys + punctuation would be useful for ip-addresses regardless of the uiculture.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Add an InputScopeNameValue for IP-address input" (#902)

Issues.Title: Ensure that implicit references for .NET Framework projects are appropriate when targeting net3x and net40
Issues.Body:
Fixes #255

Traditionally, Visual Studio has supplied these references for .NET Framework based WPF Projects: 
    
 - .NET 3.x:   PresentationCore, PresentationFramework, WindowsBase 
 - .NET 4.x:   PresentationCore, PresentationFramework, WindowsBase, System.Xaml 


    `Microsoft.NET.WindowsDesktop.SDK` will supply the following references to .NET Framework based 
    WPF Projects: 
    
    - .NET 3.x:
       - PresentationCore, PresentationFramework, WindowsBase 
    
    - .NET 4.0:   
       - PresentationCore, PresentationFramework, WindowsBase, System.Xaml, 
       - UIAutomationClient, UIAutomationClientSideProviders, UIAutomationProvider, UIAutomationTypes
                
    - .NET 4.5+:  
       - PresentationCore, PresentationFramework, WindowsBase, System.Xaml, 
        - UIAutomationClient, UIAutomationClientSideProviders, UIAutomationProvider, UIAutomationTypes
         - System.Windows.Controls.Ribbon

Also adds `$(_MicrosoftNetSdkWindowsDesktop)` . This can be used later in `Microsoft.NET.Sdk` to test whether properties like `UseWpf` or `UseWindowsForms` are set without import `Microsoft.NET.Sdk.WindowsDesktop` and show a warning.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Ensure that implicit references for .NET Framework projects are appropriate when targeting net3x and net40" (#881)

Issues.Title: port 2 changes from .NET 4.8: crash in PropertyChangeEventManager and GDI handle leak
Issues.Body: Fixes #896, fixes #897.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "port 2 changes from .NET 4.8: crash in PropertyChangeEventManager and GDI handle leak" (#899)

Issues.Title: WPF UserControl Hosted in Winform - NullReferenceException
Issues.Body:
(Port of bugfix in .NET 4.8)

The issues is that when a WPF UserControl has a reference to the Form hosting (using ElementHost) and the UserControl tries to close the Form from a keystroke it will cause a NullReferenceException.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "WPF UserControl Hosted in Winform - NullReferenceException" (#898)

Issues.Title: GDI handle leak when application is PerMonV2 aware
Issues.Body:
(Port of bugfix in .NET 4.8)

The root cause for this is a handle leak in WindowStartupTopLeftPointHelper.IdentifyScreenTopLeft when the application is PerMonV2 aware.

The screen HDC used in this function is never released.  This causes a GC when the window being created paints as DoPaint's HDC creation will always push the handle count in HandleCollector.HandleType above the threshold value.  So a new window, in most scenarios under PerMonV2, will cause a GC.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "GDI handle leak when application is PerMonV2 aware" (#897)

Issues.Title: WPF application crashes with System.InvalidOperationException: Collection was modified after the enumerator was instantiated. at System.Collections.Specialized.ListDictionary.NodeEnumerator.MoveNext()
Issues.Body:
(Port of bugfix in .NET 4.8)

The exception occurs as follows:

1. A property is changed
2. The weak-event system starts delivery of the PropertyChanged event
3. One of the handlers calls (indirectly) a method that
4. Pushes a dispatcher frame, starting a nested message pump
5. A cleanup task reaches the front of the dispatcher queue (before the frame stops pumping)
6. PropertyChangedEventManager.Purge iterates over its dictionary.  When it reaches the ListenerList corresponding to the property from (1), it's marked "in-use" (from (2)), so the list is cloned and the clone is inserted into the dictionary.
7. The next MoveNext() from (6) throws the exception.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "WPF application crashes with System.InvalidOperationException: Collection was modified after the enumerator was instantiated. at System.Collections.Specialized.ListDictionary.NodeEnumerator.MoveNext()" (#896)

Issues.Title: Infinite layout loop in Ribbon
Issues.Body:
Copied from VSO id: 911998

Found from automated test case (Case190401)

There's a bug in Ribbon where the RibbonContextualTabGroupsPanel repeatedly invalidates the RibbonTabHeadersPanel, which in turn invalidates the original RCTGP, without changing any sizes.  This leads to a soft layout loop.   It only happens with certain sizes (which have only appeared on RS3+ machines, perhaps due to theme differences and/or mouse-move coalescing).

This breaks the test case, which waits for DispatcherPriority.ApplicationIdle.  The soft loop repeatedly posts higher-priority tasks, attempting to finish a layout pass, so the test case eventually times out.

This can happen to users, if they resize the ribbon in just the wrong way.  The symptom would be high CPU usage.  However the app is still responsive, and the user can resize the window to a less unfortunate size, and the CPU will return to 0.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Infinite layout loop in Ribbon" (#895)

Issues.Title: An ActiveX control hosted in a WindowsFormsHost is redrawn incorrectly after resizing the host window.
Issues.Body: * .NET Core Version: (e.g. 3.0 Preview15-27626-15) * Windows version: (1809(OS Build 17763.503) * Does the bug reproduce also in WPF for .NET Framework 4.8?: No in 4.7.2 ActiveX control is redrawn shifted to the left and up such that its left and top edge are clipped when the control has focus and the window is resized. The control continues to shift left and up as the above steps are repeated. I found this issue while attempting to port our code to Core3. We have a highly customized ActiveX graphing control that we moved from MFC to WPF a couple of years ago. We are now moving to Core 3 and noticed a problem with the control. When a user clicks on the graph it is redrawn shifted to the left and up such that its left and top edge are clipped. We then tested several other ActiveX components and found similar behavior although resizing the host window was required to reproduce the shifted drawing. Just to rule out our ActiveX controls we built a sample button from GetHub\VCSamples-master\VC2008Samples\MFC\controls\button and observed the same behavior although it throws a pair of unrelated exceptions when the window loses focus. Expected Behavior: Building the same application but using .Net 4.7.2 does not display the drawing defect although the exceptions are thrown by the sample button. The control simply changes size as the window changes size. Minimal Repro: Using Visual Studio 2019 Preview Version 16.1.0 Preview 3.0 create a new WPF application using .NET Core 3. Add to the MainWindow.xaml a Loaded event and a 3x3 grid containing a WindowsFormsHost in row 1 column 1. Set the background property of the WindowsFormsHost to yellow and the grid background to azure or any contrasting color. To Dependencies add a registered ActiveX component wrapped by aximp.exe to the Assemblies and add NuGet Microsoft.NETCore.App.Host.win-x86 (3.0.0-preview5-27626-15). In MainWindow.xaml.cs add the Window_Loaded event and within the function new the button and assign it to WindowsFormsHost.Child. Alternatively the two projects at https://1drv.ms/f/s!AB8PEB5wHC4Jeg contain the button control and the WPF application. After building the button control register it using regsvr32. Then create the import wrapper by running aximp.exe. In my case C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft SDKs\Windows\v10.0A\bin\NETFX 4.7.2 Tools>aximp.exe button.ocx /out: C:\Download\MS MFC Samples\GetHub\VCSamples-master\VC2008Samples\MFC\controls\button\Debug\AxInterop.button.dll Next build the WPF application and ensure the following dependencies: Under Assemblies AxInterop.button NuGet Microsoft.NETCore.App.Host.win-x86 (3.0.0-preview5-27626-15) 1. Run the app 2. click the button 3. Resize the window by dragging lower right corner 4. button is redrawn with boarder on all sides 5. Minimize the window 6. Restore the window. Button is now drawn in the upper left corner of the WindowsFormsHost 7. Repeat steps 2-4, button is redrawn with small boarder at top-left, larger boarder bottom-right. 8. Repeat steps 5-6, button is redrawn in upper left corner with large boarder at bottom-right. 9. As these steps are repeated the button's upper left corner is increasingly clipped.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "An ActiveX control hosted in a WindowsFormsHost is redrawn incorrectly after resizing the host window." (#878)

@robertborr commented on [Thu Jun 06 2019](https://github.com/dotnet/core-eng/issues/6649#issuecomment-499669802)

Cc: @stevenbrix
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "queue is not allowed for authenticated usage build failures in 'official/$(reponame)/refs/heads/master' - '20190606.7'" (#889)

Issues.Title: fix helix target queues
Issues.Body:
fixing helix queues. we can't have a queue that ends with ".Open" for internal builds.

Fixes #889
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix helix target queues" (#888)

Issues.Title: WPF Toolkit and Futures
Issues.Body:
WPF Toolkit and Futures (and a few other goodies) located at https://archive.codeplex.com/?p=wpf were the first parts of wpf to be open-sourced AFAIK.

Are there plans to merge those back in this repository in any form?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "WPF Toolkit and Futures" (#887)

Issues.Title: Remove null reference workaround for PresentationFramework-SystemXmlLinq
Issues.Body:
Remove workaround for https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/issues/32641.

Fixes #743
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Remove null reference workaround for PresentationFramework-SystemXmlLinq" (#882)

The following updates ensure that dependencies with a *CoherentParentDependency*
attribute were produced in a build used as input to the parent dependency's build.
See [Dependency Description Format](https://github.com/dotnet/arcade/blob/master/Documentation/DependencyDescriptionFormat.md#dependency-description-overview)

Issues.Body:
Set Quiet on ILAsm and NoBar on ILDAsm.

Fixes #875
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Suppress all GUI from IL(D)Asm calls." (#877)

Issues.Title: WIP - Enable APICompat in WPF Builds
Issues.Body:
Fixes #724 

See: https://github.com/rladuca/ApiCompatNotes/blob/master/ApiCompat%20Notes.txt

This sets up and enables API Compat against .NET 4.8 reference assemblies and also ensures compat between hand-crafted ref assemblies and their lib counterparts.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "WIP - Enable APICompat in WPF Builds" (#880)
